trial_identification.studytitle: DISCOVERing Treatment Reality of Type 2 Diabetes in Real World Settings
trial_identification.scientifictitle: DISCOVERing Treatment Reality of Type 2 Diabetes in Real World Settings

interventions.interventions: One single cohort. - One single cohort of patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus initiating their second line anti-diabetic therapy after first line anti-diabetic therapy.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Anti-diabetic treatments prescribed by physicians in a real-world setting. - The drugs (or their combinations) prescribed by physicians to patients initiating a 2nd line anti-diabetic treatment in a real-world setting will be described at inclusion and during 3 years follow-up.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Disease control in terms of achieving HbA1c target goals and reducing body weight and blood pressure.
Disease progression (incidence of microvascular and macrovascular complications).
Quality of Life, using Patient Reported Outcomes questionnaires.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
1. Provision of subject informed consent
2. Female or male aged 18 years and over
3. Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus
4. Initiating a second line anti-diabetic therapy, either as add-on, or switching from one monotherapy to another.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
1. Diagnosis of type 1 diabetes mellitus
2. Patient is pregnant
3. Patients initiating a dual therapy after having previously received two different lines of monotherapy before (e.g.: Metformin ? SU (Sulphonylureas) ? SU+Add-on)
4. Current treatment with chemotherapy, oral or iv steroids
5. Patient is on dialysis or has had a renal transplant
6. The patient is taking insulin as first line treatment
7. The patient is taking dual therapy or a fixed dose combination treatment as first line treatment.
8. The patient is taking herbal remedies / natural medicines as first line treatment
9. Participation in an interventional trial
10. Presence of any condition/circumstance which in the opinion of the investigator could significantly limit the complete follow up of the patient for 3 years (e.g. lifethreatening co-morbidities, tourist, non-native speaker or does not understand the local language where interpreter services are not reliably available, psychiatric disturbances, dementia, alcohol or drug abuse).
11. Not willing to sign the informed consent.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: DISCOVER is a Non Interventional Study study to describe the disease management patterns and clinical evolution over three years in type 2 diabetes mellitus patients initiating a second line anti-diabetic treatment.
